channel.title: Need tips on upgrading
channel.description:
Okay. So, I want to upgrade soon, with the price hopefully being less than 1.5k. I currently have:
[ul]Quad Core AMD Phenom 9500. (Might be slightly heat damaged.) Nvida 9800GTX+ PCI-E 512mb. (Taken a bit of a beating.) 1.5tb/200gig Sata HD's MSI MS-7367 Motherboard. 2Gig Kingston RAM[/ul]
I want to have something like:
[ul]i7 Quad Intel core (Don't know any good models) Either a ATI Radeon™ HD 5970, or similar. (I need to get some information from others to go to Nvidia or ATI.) 4gig + RAM A decent, good quality big gaming/air cooling case. I refuse to get water for fear of pipes bursting. I hate water, love air - just me. Because of my current case and motherboard layout, I had to melt the shroud of my Vcard just to fit it in. A DECENT motherboard than the shitty one I have.[/ul]
Also, a good quality, cheap place to get these. I used to get my parts from MSY but I suspect there's other places that people might have struck gold. Halp please?

item.title: Need tips on upgrading
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

goatee:

Why would mineral oil keep it cool? Surely the oil would just heat up?

Then cool the oil down…

Read full topic

item.title: Need tips on upgrading
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

goatee:

Why would mineral oil keep it cool? Surely the oil would just heat up?

it conducts heat much better than air

Read full topic

item.title: Need tips on upgrading

Why would mineral oil keep it cool? Surely the oil would just heat up?

item.title: Need tips on upgrading
item.dc:creator: @zoss0 Zoss
item.description:
@zoss0 wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:4, topic:338968”]If you’re going to change processors, take into account that you will need a new motherboard. Asus makes some great i5/i7/all motherboards. I would probably stick with nVidia for an intel processor. Don’t ask me why, they just seem to go well. CoolMasters make fuckin’ delicious cases. And I think it’s more of an oil than water. I would see oil as a better heat conductor.

Edit: I remember seeing a video of a computer completely submerged in a certain oil. I forget what it was, but I would definitely hate to have to replace a part in that haha.[/quote]
Taking that into account, where would you buy your parts from?
Also, what motherboard would you recommend (being specific-wise, not just brand-wise.)?

[quote=“T4_, post:2, topic:338968”]You seem oddly familiar.

Nevermind.[/quote]
Lolwut?

Read full topic

Edit: I remember seeing a video of a computer completely submerged in a certain oil. I forget what it was, but I would definitely hate to have to replace a part in that haha.

item.title: Need tips on upgrading
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

You can get the corsair h50 cooler and its closed loop so you never have to change it or deal with it.

item.title: Need tips on upgrading
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

If you’re going to change processors, take into account that you will need a new motherboard. Asus makes some great i5/i7/all motherboards. I would probably stick with nVidia for an intel processor. Don’t ask me why, they just seem to go well. CoolMasters make fuckin’ delicious cases. And I think it’s more of an oil than water. I would see oil as a better heat conductor.

Edit: I remember seeing a video of a computer completely submerged in a certain oil. I forget what it was, but I would definitely hate to have to replace a part in that haha.

Read full topic
